data.title: Add Keymap & Video Help Menu Items
data.body:
Hi,

We are going to create a single page cheat sheet for keybindings.  This should be linked from the help menu.  We have a different link for each OS.

The item should be `Keymap Reference`.
- MacOS: `https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=832143`
- Linux: `https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=832144`
- Windows: `https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=832145`

Currently the links point to the webpage on the website - but by the time we ship stable we will have the nice PDF versions.

We should also include a link for `Introductory Videos` which will use the single fwd link of:
- `https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=832146`

This is inspired by what WebStorm does.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1051190/19554585/9732d1d6-96b9-11e6-9213-91564fd45941.png)

cc @gregvanl , @waderyan

data.title: Hot Exit: textFileEditorModel has ugly duplication in load() method
data.body: I see quite some duplication in that method depending on wether a backup resource is present or not, please merge into one.

data.title: Breakpoint doesn't work well with typescript + mocha
data.body:
I'm working on a typescript project, using mocha as unit-test.
The debug mode worked fine on vscode v1.5.3.
After upgrading to 1.6.0 and later versions, it suspends at the first breakpoint, then auto-resume after like 1 sec, and skips all other breakpoints till done.
Another strange thing is "mocha --debug-brk" service with be terminated after that.

It works again after downgrade to v1.5.3.
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start a typescript project.
2. Write some test case using mocha.
3. Setup launch config with sourceMaps=true.
4. Run mocha --debug-brk.
5. Add some breakpoints in testcase.
6. Debug run.

data.title: Hot Exit: do not load backup files to restore sync on startup in the renderer
data.body: I notice that you load all files to restore on startup sync in `workbench.ts`. That is terrible, instead the main side should pass over this information as part of the window opening and the renderer just reads it out of there.

data.title: Hot Exit: Restore untitled files from within UntitledEditorModel
data.body: I see the motivation for this but it goes through so many layers that we should NOT have this at all. Both untitled and text file world in the end have a good place where you should check for backups and get the contents from there: `TextEditorModel.load()`. That is the only safe place to know if a backup is present and to restore it, everything else is just fragile.

data.title: Hot Exit: backupService.ts feedback
data.body:
Some feedback:

I notice that you have some test methods in here, I typically would rather have a subclass for testing purposes to make it clearer that a method is only used from tests (that is more a personal taste).

You could use `process.type` to check if you are in the renderer or browser process. Though given my other feedback of splitting services up, I think the renderer should not have a dependency to this backup workspace management service. 

You should not call `fs.existsSync()`, just call `fs.readFile()` and handle the error. That saves you one fs call. 

The `setCurrentWorkspace` is very ugly. Instead I would pass in the `IWorkspaceContextService` as optional dependency and get the workspace from there. Though again, given my feedback on splitting up services, I think this method is a good indication that we need 2 services: one for main side to manager backup workspaces and one for the renderer to backup files.

data.title: Hot Exit: push renderer backup logic into new backup service
data.body:
I notice that many backup related tasks are spread and tightly coupled in many places of untitled world and files world. This is a larger issue where I think the theme should be to LOOSEN the tight coupling of backup to the rest by leveraging more events and services. I am not a big fan of adding all backup matters into the pieces we have today. Instead this should be an optional service that is plugged in from the outside as much as that is possible.

I suggest to introduce a new service for backup handling from the renderer that deals with all these matters. 

It should contain all the methods of `IFileService` for backup related work and just use the IFileService where appropriate. 

It should listen to dirty events from the untitled and text file land and start the business of doing a backup (after a delay - for that take a look into `async.ts/RunOnceScheduler`) as well as cleaning up backups when a file is no longer dirty or the model gets disposed. This also makes it possible to reuse the same code between backing up untitled and text files.

It should answer to the question if hot exist is enabled or not for the workspace. 

It should participate in the shutdown lifecycle and do the things that `ITextFileServices` today does. I do not expect to see any backup related code in `ITextFileServices`, the only thing it should do is check for the hot exit flag to ask for confirmation or not.

data.title: Hot Exit: backupService saves and loads a LOT
data.body:
I do not understand why the `backupService.ts`needs to sync save and load on basically every method invocation. We already ensure that at any time only one main process can be running so I think also only one process ever writes to `workspaces.json` in the backups folder.

I suggest to look at `storage.ts` in `electron-main` as an example and just keep the workspaces in memory and not load/save every time.

data.title: Hot Exit: deal with backup workspaces that do not exist anymore
data.body: On startup you add workspaces to open that have backups. What if this workspace meanwhile got deleted? You should check this on startup and remove the backup workspace from `workspaces.json` if you detect it does not exist anymore.

data.title: Hot Exit: get rid of options.restoreBackups
data.body: It seems that you only want to restore backups on a first startup and so I find it weird to move this into the `windows.open()` method that gets called from so many other places. Instead I suggest to move this into `main.ts` and add the workspaces to open from there.

data.title: JavaScript code coloring bug when comma separated var
`Launch VSCode` target launches multiple window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: master
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

I was rebasing my PR against master, but this happens:

When I do `npm run watch` + `F5`
- First time, one window open for project A.
- Cmd+o, open another project B that's not opened in any windows
- Close all windows and restart the instance again, VSCode still launches two windows, one for A and one for B.

Now I've used my build to open a few more projects...And I have 4 windows open....
Here is a gif of me adding yet another one

![multiple](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/19552829/66d6374c-9666-11e6-8085-7ef331068555.gif)

I guess it's related to hot exit.

/cc @bpasero @Tyriar

data.title: 2 compilation errors in `gulp watch` from scratch
data.body:
Just came back from vacation. Did `git clean -xfd .`, `./scripts/npm.sh install` and `gulp watch`.

Ended up with these errors in `gulp watch`:

```
[10:15:54] Error: /Users/joao/Work/vscode/extensions/vscode-api-tests/node_modules/vscode/vscode.d.ts(6,10): Cannot find name 'vscode'.
[10:15:54] Error: /Users/joao/Work/vscode/extensions/vscode-colorize-tests/node_modules/vscode/vscode.d.ts(6,10): Cannot find name 'vscode'.
[10:15:54] Finished compilation with 2 errors after 34554 ms
```

Assigning to you @jrieken since you seem to be the last guy touching it, although I'm not sure you are the source of the issue.

data.title: Watermark commands not lined up
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/19552016/db9cdf9e-9662-11e6-8652-d095e76e7663.png)

The up and down arrow are off.

Because the arrow key falls through all provided fonts and get rendered in Arial.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/19552102/42a5dc4a-9663-11e6-880c-e424d8c89697.png)

I suggest adding Lucida Grande to the font-family, for `.shortcut` in macOS's watermark.

data.title: Hot Exit: how do you deal with the same file opened twice in multiple windows?
data.body:
It is possible to open the same file in multiple windows even if those windows have workspaces associated. You can just File > Open and pick any file on disk.

How is this handled today? Isn't it weird to associate a backup to a file that is outside of the workspace to the backup story of a specific workspace?

data.title: Hot Exit: backup workspace handling should all happen on main side
data.body:
I find it weird that the main side adds a workspace to the backup service but the renderer removes it again on close. I think the window should not deal with this matter and instead let the main side deal with backup workspace management. 

For that I suggest to split the backup service into two pieces: one that deals with backup workspace management only from the main side and then a backup-file-service that deals with all the backup methods that the workbench needs (even fine by me to move this into the workbench services part).

The backup workspace service in `electron-main` listens to lifecycle and window events to manage backup workspaces. Each window object has an associated workspace path so you can use that. It:
- adds a workspace to the backup on open
- removes a workspace from backup on close if there are no backups anymore
- same for exit

data.title: Hot Exit: avoid direct calls to fs.readdir()/fs.readdirSync()
data.body: I noticed you are calling `fs.readdir()/fs.readdirSync()`. These methods cannot be used standalone, instead please use `pfs.readdir()/pfs.readdirSync()`. These use `extfs` to deal with some exotic corner cases of unicode normalization in paths.

data.title: Hot Exit: properly deal with backups to files that got deleted
data.body: Today a workspace path is the identifier for a backup but you need to consider the case of a folder getting deleted and recreated with the same name. For that, each `IWorkspace` object carries an identifier (this is actually the `ctime`). You need to take this into account when finding backups and you need to discard backups if you detect that a workspace with same path but different ID is opened.

data.title: Hot Exit: unused imports in some files
data.body: It does not seem like you have `ghooks` installed that would prevent checking in code with warnings. I found unused imports in `backupService.test.ts` and `fileServices.test.ts`.

data.title: Hot Exit: promise handling is often bad
data.body:
I found many places where a method is called that actually returns a `promise`. Without adding a `done` handler you swallow possible errors and also make it very hard to understand that a method call is a long running operation.

A typical pattern we use is `method().done(null, errors.onUnhandledException)`. 

Examples: `untitledEditorModel`

data.title: Navigating via require statements in JavaScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04
- Language: JavaScript
  I am able to navigate through require statements in JavaScript. It directs me to the file, when I press ctrl+click on a required file.

My friend is also using VSC and getting intellisense, but he is not able to jump through files via require statement.

I am unable to find a setting which is different in our VSC. 
jsconfig.js file is the same in both our projects and I am unable to find a setting that controls this behavior. 
I may be missing something trivial here, but how can I enable this feature everywhere.

Thanks

data.title: Declarative contribution of custom Tree Explorer
data.body:
PR for #12163.
### Main changes:
- `contributes.explorer` section for letting extension add custom tree explorers
- `TreeExplorerNodeProvider<T>` in vscode namespace
- `registerTreeExplorerNodeProvider(providerId: string, provider: TreeExplorerNodeProvider<any>): Disposable` in vscode namespace
- `vs/workbench/parts/explorers/*`
  - The viewlet for tree explorers
  - Command to toggle each tree explorer
### Not yet implemented:
- [x] Handle long running `TreeExplorerNodeProvider.provideRootNode` and `TreeExplorerNodeProvider.resolveChildren` by adding a progress bar.
- [x] Handle restoring external viewlet if last active viewlet is external.
  - Construct blank sidebar and restore external viewlet after it gets registered
  - Show progress bar at top of the blank sidebar while waiting for external viewlet getting registered
- [x] Refresh button at top of external viewlet
- [x] Show error popup for handling errors in `TreeExplorerNodeProvider`'s methods.
- [x] Show error popup for no matching `TreeExplorerNodeProvider` found
- [x] Use `-webkit-filter` and opacity to style user defined activity bar icons to indicate activation.
- [ ] Add extension that test against the API
### High level flow
- Workbench get constructed
- Stock Viewlets get registered
- Extensions' `package.json` get read.
- `ViewletDescriptor` for external viewlets get registered at `ViewletRegistry`
- `ActivitybarPart` adds icons for external viewlets when external viewlets finish registration 
- When icon for external viewlet get clicked, construct the viewlet and hook it to the registered provider
### Examples
- [Deps](https://github.com/octref/explorer-api-example/tree/master/dep): easiest to get running.
- [Avatar](https://github.com/octref/explorer-api-example/tree/master/avatar): need to get a GH token. See `src/token.ts`.
- [Redis](https://github.com/octref/explorer-api-example/tree/master/redis): need to install redis.

data.title: Follow symlinks recursively in Linux launch script
data.body: fixes #14044, see the issue report for details.

data.title: JavaScript & TypeScript formatting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro (10586.494)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new JavaScript file (same problem with a TypeScript file)
2. Add a function
3. Pressing Alt + Shift + F does nothing (nor does clicking on the right click menu shortcut)

Example code:

`function test(arg) {console.log(arg);};`

I would expected the code above to have been formatted like so:

```
function test(arg) {
    console.log(arg);
};
```

data.title: It's better to follow symlinks recursively in Linux launch script
data.body:
The Linux launch script (`bin/code`) of vscode finds `VSCODE_PATH` by resolving the path of itself:

``` bash
VSCODE_PATH="$(dirname $(readlink $0))/.."
```

Some users might want to use symlinks that link to symlink of `bin/code`, then this script will fail to launch vscode, because it only follows one layer of symlinks. To solve this problem, simply add `-f` option to `readlink` to resolve the symlinks recursively:

``` bash
VSCODE_PATH="$(dirname $(readlink -f $0))/.."
```

A pull request is on the way.

Now, that we are on 2.0 we should consider migrating to consume typings through npm.
